ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I familiarized myself with the genre of auto-criticism and in general received so much helpful feedback on my original piece, which I produced many iterations of throughout the semester. I think I became a more thoughtful, vulnerable writer through this process and through getting to give and receive feedback. I also developed a better understanding of the process of writing about oneself through our q&as with various guest speakers.

how to ask meaningful questions. how to read and understand the world more intimately and use this reading to sustain our collective continuance. workshopping our 'autocriticism' throughout the semester not only enriched each of our writing abilities but improved our capacity to engage editing in the long-term, a skill that is neglected in most Yale writing courses.

In this course, I gained personal reflection and memoir writing skills. I also think that I grew as a constructive critic through the course's workshops, in which I learned more about giving good feedback.

learned about different forms of auto-criticism, about how writers discussed their relationship with their parents, friends, partners, cultural identities, gender identities, etc in relation to different art forms
I learned what it means to write auto-critically which was incredibly powerful and healing for me.
What auto-criticism means, personal writing, how to close read a memoir

I was completely new to autocriticism before taking the course. Through reading various models of autocriticism and working on my own piece, I developed an understanding of what can happen when a writer brings the self into contact with a piece of media, another person, a place or a larger system in the world. The course strengthened my close, critical reading skills, my ability to recognize and articulate craft in writing, and my comfort giving feedback in workshops. I also loved getting to spend the second half of the semester working on one piece of writing, which I don't think I've gotten the chance to do in other writing classes at Yale. It taught me how to think deeply and slowly about an idea, revise multiple times, and incorporate suggestions to make something I ultimately feel proud of.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Rankine and Professor Mirakhor are both brilliant and give you really helpful, generous feedback on your work. They created a supportive class community of writers and thinkers who were all invested in the process. I also appreciated how this course structured the final project to have multiple deadlines throughout the semester so that it wasn't overwhelming at the end. We also had access to some really wonderful guest speakers.

Weaknesses: Really can't think of much other than that the syllabus wasn't fully finalized at the beginning of the semester and sometimes changes were communicated the day before class.

no weaknesses! strengths: (1) professor mirakhor and professor rankine's superb facilitation and insightful comments; (2) class visits from prominent writers; (3) alternating discussion posts; (4) syllabus; (5) allocation of workshopping time!

The biggest strength of this course is its instructors, both of whom gave constructive, clear feedback on my writing that truly helped me grow. Neither of them were shy about giving honest feedback on writing that was sub-par, but both were incredibly helpful. This course's greatest weakness was the poor definition of "auto-crit," which really tripped me up at the beginning fo the course. At the beginning of the course, I was very stressed about finding a topic because I didn't fully understand the assignment or the instructors' in-class explanations.

strength - professors were good at facilitating discussion and integrating everyone into the conversation so everyone has the chance to speak
weaknesses - syllabus wasn't updated and re-uploaded with changes in deadlines or books we needed to read so it was very disorganized; for workshopping, wish there were clearer guidelines for the person giving feedback to write enough comments

The course is strong because it really just focused on our ability to read and write auto-criticisms and engage with this work via discussion. The focus was on our learning and not necessarily assignments.
Wish it couldve been in person but it was great to have the authors of the books we read come to lecture!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: N/A
success: flexibility on assignment deadlines and understanding of students' circumstances. areas of improvement: none!
While the unmuted Zoom room was sometimes a struggle for me, I really do think that it helped me stay engaged with the course and connect with my classmates.
Canvas discussion posts were great
Flexibility with due dates and online conversations were helpful!
Having the opportunity to speak to nearly all of the authors we read was a fantastic way to enrich the course in a virtual format.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, most definitely! It will truly change your perspective on the writing process and expose you to some great work of classmates' and other writers/memoirists. Most of all, Professor Rankine and Professor Mirakhor are a joy to work with.
yes yes yes! should this course be offered again, you'll find that the way you approach your subject self, the world, reading, and writing to be entirely transformed.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student who is able to self-direct their learning to a certain degree, but also thrives on good criticism from the professors.

it's intense! a lot of emotional labor as you process your auto-criticism essay topic. everyone is expected to bring their A-game to discussion posts and class discussions, so you need to be invested and not fall behind, otherwise you'll miss out on a lot!
I absolutely recommend this course!!! One of my favorites I have taken at Yale!
Yes! Great course with amazing professors

Absolutely - this was without a doubt one of the best classes I've taken during my time at Yale. Prof. Mirakhor and Prof. Rankine were incredible teachers in their writing feedback and conduction of class discussions. The course really allows you to build a small community while discussing, writing, and workshopping personal essays with each other.

Yes, 100%. If you're at all interested in reading or writing memoir or criticism, this class is completely mind-opening and exciting. Truly, every day you will leave class with SO many new thoughts and ideas and connections between readings.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
Virtual seminar, virtual author visits

extras.title:
AFAM 395 01/ER&M 294 01/ENGL 296 01
        Writing the Self in the World
